Comment: This was a close tactical game involving the Advance Variation of the Caro Kann. Although it was decided by a mistake, it is of some interest for me to analyse some of the departures from theory in the late opening and the complicated position that arose in the middle game.
The Caro Advance.
The Caro Advance.
The Caro Advance.
The Caro Advance.
Black gets his bishop outside his pawn skeleton - the main point in playing the Caro Kann.
Preparing to go into to the aggressive Bayonnet Variation after 4 ...e6, 5. g4!? A quieter alternative, quite popular nowadays, is Short's 4. Nf3.
The main alternative to 4. ...e6. Black opts to steer the game into other channels.
The usual deployment for the KN, though it has its pros and cons.
The usual deployment for the KN, though it has its pros and cons.

Aiming to gain a little space on the queenside at the expense of the black queen.
Aiming to gain a little space on the queenside at the expense of the black queen.
Aiming to gain a little space on the queenside at the expense of the black queen.
Aiming to gain a little space on the queenside at the expense of the black queen.
An important move, given that black plans ...c5. A white knight landing on b5 would be very problematic.
Again a thematic move in this variation. The queen exerts pressure on the kingside and especially e6.
The optimal posting for the knight - the question is whether it is premature.
This seems to be a popular move, though the theory I know says ...Qd8. The present move gives good support to the centre, but excludes the option of challenging the white queen on h4.
This seems to be a popular move, though the theory I know says ...Qd8. The present move gives good support to the centre, but excludes the option of challenging the white queen on h4.

Theory, as far as I know, has Nd1 at this point, preparing to break open the centre with c4. I won with that in another annotated game (vs caimig), but was a bit unconvinced by it, and opted for this aggressive lunge instead. Strategically the idea is similar, to take advantage of black's slow and slightly cramped development.
Preparing to meet black's counter-attack in the centre. I am relying on this bishop to hold things together while I prepare to advance the f-pawn.
Preparing to meet black's counter-attack in the centre. I am relying on this bishop to hold things together while I prepare to advance the f-pawn.
The thematic counter-attack.
Putting pressure on f5 and e6.
Putting pressure on f5 and e6.
Putting pressure on f5 and e6.
Preparing to exchange off the white knight as well as threatening the a-pawn.
Black decides that the knight has to go.
